slidelink.displaytext: Types of Mixed Methods research q's

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: (A Transcript will be posted here when there is dialog)
(A Transcript will be posted here when there is dialog)
HI everyone! Today’s talk will focus on mixed-methods research design.

Here’s one scenario that is appropriate for mixed-methods design. (pause and have student read scenario) - [continue]

A study shows slight negative correlation between time on home computer and student GPA.

However, the number did not tell us why this is happening.

It is a good idea to conduct interviews or observation to explain why.

In a mixed-methods research, you are encouraged to utilize multiple research methods to understand an educational issue.

I will provide more details in the following slides.

The objectives of this presentation are to help you:

• Understand what mixed-methods design is

• Identify the context to use mixed-methods design

• Distinguish the types of mixed-methods design

• Explain the steps in conducting mixed-methods design

Here’s a very brief history of mixed-methods research.

It was first suggested in the 1950s in the work of Campbell and Fiske.

They argued that validity always requires multiple methods and data sources.

Denzin (1978) and Jick (1979) used the term “triangulation” to refer to using multiple methods and/or types of data to study the same research question.

Many researchers in the 1970s and 80s were “purists” who held that quantitative and qualitative paradigms could not be combined.

Many now are “pragmatists” who believe that researchers should use whatever works, including mixed-methods approaches.

What is mixed-methods research?

It is a research design that utilizes both quantitative and qualitative methods in a single study.

Why do researchers utilize Mixed-Methods studies?

Sometimes, a single research method may not tell the full picture of the story.

We need to use both quantitative and qualitative data to answer the research questions.

For example, a superintendent wants to understand the causes contributing to the rise of drug use in the district.

He or she may hire a research team to first conduct a quantitative survey to find out the percentage of students using drug.

The research team will later conduct interviews with students who took the survey to understand the reasons because knowing the percentage of drug users is only the first step to combat drug uses.

Knowing the reasons will help educational professionals and policy makers to work on interventions to reduce drug uses in school.

How do you conduct mixed-methods research?

Creswell (2008) suggested seven steps to conduct mixed-methods studies.

The first step is to establish feasibility, meaning, you need to make sure that the levels of training and expertise of the researchers or team as well as the time and resources for data collection and analysis are adequate.

The second step is to identify the rationale.

Think why it is important to conduct this mixed-method research.

Can you justify your purpose clearly to people reading your research?

The third step is to determine the design, who are your subjects and what kind of data you will collect?

Also, what kind of mixed-methods research, is it explanatory sequential, exploratory sequential, or convergent?

The fourth step is to establish specific quantitative and qualitative research questions.

Align the research questions with the purpose and design elements of mixed-methods procedures.

In other words, your questions should reflect the research design and can be answered by the identified data collection methods.

For example, if the research question is to study participant perceptions on certain issue.

The researcher can collect the data from surveys, interviews, focus group, or other methods.

Typically, researchers will develop separate quantitative and qualitative questions into a study.

When developing the research questions, keep the data collection in mind.

If it’s an explanatory sequential, you need to collect quantitative data prior to qualitative data.

If it’s an explorative sequential, you need to collect qualitative data before quantitative data.

The fifth step is to collect the data.

You need to identify the sequence of data collection when you choose the type of design for your research.

The process will be longer than regular study unless you conduct a convergent research that quantitative and qualitative data are collected at the same time period.

The sixth step is to analyze the data.

Quantitative data and qualitative data should be analyzed separately and independently.

Based on the research design, the researcher can then decide what data can be used to answer which research question.

The data can be combined to answer one research question.

For example, both survey results and focus group interviews can be used to answer the question of student perceptions on a certain issue.

They can complement each other.

The seventh step is to write the report.

Again, writing the results in the report is pending on the research design.

It is important to explain clearly the procedures employed in both quantitative and qualitative components of the study.

Usually they are reported separately in different sections in the report.

However, if it’s a convergent design, the data can be integrated around the research questions into the same section of the final report.

We will explain the types of mixed-methods research design in the next few slides.

There are three types of mixed-methods design.

The first one is explanatory sequential design in which quantitative methods are followed by the qualitative methods.

For example, you would administer a survey first and then conduct interviews.

-----

The second one is exploratory sequential design in which the qualitative methods are followed by the quantitative methods. For example, you would go into a school to observe common teaching practices with iPad and then administer a survey to see the common patterns in utilizing iPad in the classroom.

-----

The third one is convergent, also called triangulation design, in which both quantitative methods and qualitative methods are implemented more or less at the same time.

For example, you would administer a survey and conduct interviews roughly at the same time period to save time.

The researchers can then see if multiple sources of data can be triangulated to help explain the patterns of iPad uses in the classroom and why.
(Knowledge Check)

I mentioned earlier that explanatory sequential design starts with quantitative methods and followed by qualitative methods.

Here is one specific example of explanatory sequential design.

The researchers want to understand the patterns of teachers’ grading practice and understand why zero-based grading is utilized.

Researchers have observed that giving students zero point can pose psychological stress and anxiety.

What is the rationale behind zero-based grading?

We can conduct an explanatory sequential design that uses a teacher survey about grading practices first.

After analyzing the survey results, we can then go ahead and interview teachers to ask them explaining why zeros are used in grading students.

In this design, the quantitative research question can be:

What are teacher’s grading practices?

The survey can list a few existing practices so we can understand the patterns.

The qualitative research question would be open-ended interview question such as “why do teacher use zero in grading students” so that teachers can be open and free to provide their rationale during interviews.

Now using the same research topic but a different research design.

Let’s see how we can conduct this research using exploratory sequential design.

We can first interview teachers to understand the general grading practices.

Using the interview results, we can design a survey for a larger sample of teachers to predict the validity of scores across teachers.

In other words, do the scoring systems from different teachers measure the same student outcomes?

That should be very interesting to find out.

The qualitative research question could be: “how do teachers describe their grading practice?” and the quantitative research question could be:”what is the predictive validity of the scores across teachers?”

Next using the same research topic, how do we carry out a convergent, also known as triangulation, design?

You can carry out the interviews and survey of teachers and students to understand the perceptions or rationale behind their grading systems.

This will reduce the length of time to collect data.

In order to have multiple perspectives, students are included in the study.

The quantitative research questions could be:

”What is the relationship between teacher’s grading practices and their beliefs about student ability?”

And “What is the relationship between teachers’ grading practices and student motivation?”

The data from the survey can shed light on the potential gap between teacher’s practice and student views.

Anticipating there might be a gap, we could then include questions in the interview to seek possible explanations.

The qualitative questions could be: “How do teachers describe their grading practices?”

And “How do students describe their teachers’ grading practices?”

The data will provide us a broader perspective of the grading practices perceived by both teachers and students.

Here’s a quick summary of the different methods and examples of different research questions that you can ask.

Take your time to review the questions.

We should know that not all research studies give equal weight to quantitative methods and qualitative methods.

Researchers can use different notations to indicate which method carries more weight.

Upper case letters indicate which method is given priority.

Lowercase letters indicate if a method is given less emphasis.

Arrows indicate the sequence.

Here’s the notation for convergent design.

Plus signs (+) indicate that methods occur concurrently.

Parentheses () indicate that one method is embedded in the other

The data analysis for mixed-methods studies includes quantitative and qualitative procedures.

We use one type of data to inform the other data.

For example, descriptive statistics of student test scores are used to group students into achievement-level groups, then follow-up interviews are used to explore typical study strategies of each group.

In convergent designs, data are merged to examine how various types compare.

There are advantages and disadvantages in conducting mixed-methods studies.

The advantages include:

• Provides more comprehensive data.

• Uses multiple approaches to compensate for the limitations of each method.

• Allows investigation of different types of questions within a single study.

• Allows examination of complex research questions.

• Sometimes includes triangulation to enhance credibility of the findings.

-------

The disadvantages include:

• Researcher needs skills to conduct and interpret results from both designs.

• Often requires more extensive data collection.

• Can be difficult to combine approaches, especially when writing up the report.

• Often requires more time and resources.

Carefully choose a research design that can best answer your research questions.

Here’s a recap for this lecture. We have discussed:

• What is mixed methods research?

• When to use it?

• Why use it?

• The types of mixed methods research.

• The steps to conduct mixed methods research.

• The pros and cons.

And we have reviewed a few Research examples.

I hope you have reached a better understanding of mixed-methods design.
